articles.headline: China Pushes for Quiet Burials as Coronavirus Death Toll Is Questioned
articles.snippet: Officials are ​trying to curb expressions of grief and control the narrative​ amid doubts about the official number of deaths in China.
articles.abstract: Officials are ​trying to curb expressions of grief and control the narrative​ amid doubts about the official number of deaths in China.
articles.lead_paragraph: Liu Pei’en held the small wooden box that contained his father’s remains. Only two months ago, he had helplessly clutched his father’s frail hand as the elderly man took his last breath, and the pain was still raw. He wept.
articles.byline: By Amy Qin and Cao Li

articles.headline: Holdout States Resist Calls for Stay-at-Home Orders: ‘What Are You Waiting For?’
articles.snippet: A small number of states in the Midwest and the South are under growing pressure to order all residents to stay at home to fight the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: A small number of states in the Midwest and the South are under growing pressure to order all residents to stay at home to fight the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: A surge in coronavirus deaths in the United States has prompted the vast majority of governors to order their residents to stay home, but a small number of states are resisting increasingly urgent calls to shut down.
articles.byline: By Sarah Mervosh and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Frenzy and Desperation as Small Businesses Grab for Government Aid
articles.snippet: A $349 billion program to throw them a financial lifeline got off to a rocky start on Friday as the U.S. economy continued to seize up.
articles.abstract: A $349 billion program to throw them a financial lifeline got off to a rocky start on Friday as the U.S. economy continued to seize up.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read our Coronavirus Relief Small Business F.A.Q.]
articles.byline: By Stacy Cowley and Emily Flitter

articles.headline: A Debate Over Masks Uncovers Deep White House Divisions
articles.snippet: The Trump administration remains deeply divided over whether to tell all Americans to cover their faces in public to stop the spread of coronavirus.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration remains deeply divided over whether to tell all Americans to cover their faces in public to stop the spread of coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Friday that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention was urging all Americans to wear a mask when they leave their homes, but he immediately undercut the message by repeatedly calling the recommendation voluntary and promising that he would not wear one himself.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Sheila Kaplan

articles.headline: The Killer Flu of 1918: A Philadelphia Story
articles.snippet: The brutal toll taken by the flu that claimed 20,000 lives in the city has not been forgotten as Philadelphia braces for the worst of the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.abstract: The brutal toll taken by the flu that claimed 20,000 lives in the city has not been forgotten as Philadelphia braces for the worst of the coronavirus pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — At Sunday family dinners, the grandchildren would beg to hear that story again, the one about her twins in the baby carriage, and one of them was dead, and what did she do. This was when Sarah Jane Anderson would add to the collective memory of a Philadelphia nightmare.
articles.byline: By Dan Barry and Caitlin Dickerson

articles.headline: In Italy, Going Back to Work May Depend on Having the Right Antibodies
articles.snippet: Weighing an idea that might once have been relegated to science fiction, Italy once again finds itself in the unfortunate vanguard of Western democracies grappling with the coronavirus.
articles.abstract: Weighing an idea that might once have been relegated to science fiction, Italy once again finds itself in the unfortunate vanguard of Western democracies grappling with the coronavirus.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — There is a growing sense in Italy that the worst may have passed. The weeks of locking down the country, center of the world’s deadliest coronavirus outbreak, may be starting to pay off, as officials announced this week that the numbers of new infections had plateaued.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz

articles.headline: College Made Them Feel Equal. The Virus Exposed How Unequal Their Lives Are.
articles.snippet: When they were all in the same dorms and eating the same dining hall food, the disparities in students’ backgrounds weren’t as clear as they are over video chat.
articles.abstract: When they were all in the same dorms and eating the same dining hall food, the disparities in students’ backgrounds weren’t as clear as they are over video chat.
articles.lead_paragraph: The political science class was called “Forced Migration and Refugees.” Students read accounts of migrants fleeing broken economies and seeking better futures, of life plans drastically altered and the political forces that made it all seem necessary.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Casey

articles.headline: 430,000 People Have Traveled From China to U.S. Since Coronavirus Surfaced
articles.snippet: There were 1,300 direct flights to 17 cities before President Trump’s travel restrictions. Since then, nearly 40,000 Americans and other authorized travelers have made the trip, some this past week and many with spotty screening.
articles.abstract: There were 1,300 direct flights to 17 cities before President Trump’s travel restrictions. Since then, nearly 40,000 Americans and other authorized travelers have made the trip, some this past week and many with spotty screening.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since Chinese officials disclosed the outbreak of a mysterious pneumonialike illness to international health officials on New Year’s Eve, at least 430,000 people have arrived in the United States on direct flights from China, including nearly 40,000 in the two months after President Trump imposed restrictions on such travel, according to an analysis of data collected in both countries.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder, Henry Fountain, Michael H. Keller, Muyi Xiao and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Trump Proceeds With Post-Impeachment Purge Amid Pandemic
articles.snippet: The president’s decision to fire the intelligence community’s inspector general under cover of darkness indicated that his hunt for those he considers disloyal continues.
articles.abstract: The president’s decision to fire the intelligence community’s inspector general under cover of darkness indicated that his hunt for those he considers disloyal continues.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Remember the impeachment? President Trump does. Even in the middle of a deadly pandemic, he made clear on Saturday that he remained fixated on purging the government of those he believes betrayed him during the inquiry that led to his Senate trial.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker

articles.headline: Gaps in Amazon’s Response as Virus Spreads to More Than 50 Warehouses
articles.snippet: Shifting sick-leave policy and communication issues are causing employees to assert themselves after they stayed on the job.
articles.abstract: Shifting sick-leave policy and communication issues are causing employees to assert themselves after they stayed on the job.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Jonathan Bailey, a 30-year-old Amazon warehouse employee in Queens, has a system for protecting himself from the coronavirus at work. He wears a medical mask with a bandanna tied over it. When he returns to the apartment he shares with his wife, he dumps his mask, work gloves, neon green Amazon safety vest and other clothes into a plastic trash bag.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise and Kate Conger

articles.headline: Official Counts Understate the U.S. Coronavirus Death Toll
articles.snippet: Inconsistent protocols, limited resources and a patchwork of decision making have led to an undercounting of people with the coronavirus who have died, health experts say.
articles.abstract: Inconsistent protocols, limited resources and a patchwork of decision making have led to an undercounting of people with the coronavirus who have died, health experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A coroner in Indiana wanted to know if the coronavirus had killed a man in early March, but said that her health department denied a test. Paramedics in New York City say that many patients who died at home were never tested for the coronavirus, even if they showed telltale signs of infection.
articles.byline: By Sarah Kliff and Julie Bosman

articles.headline: Boris Johnson Hospitalized as Queen Urges British Resolve in Face of Epidemic
articles.snippet: Soon after Queen Elizabeth’s rare speech, the government said the prime minister, who is infected with coronavirus, had been admitted for tests.
articles.abstract: Soon after Queen Elizabeth’s rare speech, the government said the prime minister, who is infected with coronavirus, had been admitted for tests.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Boris Johnson was hospitalized on Sunday evening after 10 days of battling the coronavirus, unnerving a country that had gathered to watch Queen Elizabeth II rally fellow Britons to confront the pandemic and reassure them that when the crisis finally ebbed, “we will meet again.”
articles.byline: By Mark Landler

articles.headline: Two Veteran C.E.O.s Risk $1.8 Billion on a Streaming App. In a Pandemic.
articles.snippet: Jeffrey Katzenberg and Meg Whitman had to cancel a starry Hollywood party for their short-video platform because of the virus. But Quibi is still going live.
articles.abstract: Jeffrey Katzenberg and Meg Whitman had to cancel a starry Hollywood party for their short-video platform because of the virus. But Quibi is still going live.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — They had to cancel the premiere party. But Jeffrey Katzenberg and Meg Whitman have stuck with the April 6 start date of Quibi, the short-form video app for smartphones that they hope will attract millions of subscribers.
articles.byline: By Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: Politics Through the Looking Glass: Virus Scrambles the Left-Right Lines
articles.snippet: A huge federal disaster response, new urgency around health care and a debate over social distancing have muddled the nation’s ideological debate.
articles.abstract: A huge federal disaster response, new urgency around health care and a debate over social distancing have muddled the nation’s ideological debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 2020 edition of the Conservative Political Action Conference in Oxon Hill, Md., in February offered a theme-park version of what was to be President Trump’s re-election message: Under the banner of “America vs. Socialism,” the convention featured anti-Marx branded popcorn, an RV emblazed with the words “Socialism Takes Capitalism Creates” and a children’s book promoting personal freedom and private-property rights.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: Amid Warnings of a Coronavirus ‘Pearl Harbor,’ Governors Walk a Fine Line
articles.snippet: As officials warned people to brace for a surge in cases and deaths, governors pleaded for a consistent strategy and more help from Washington.
articles.abstract: As officials warned people to brace for a surge in cases and deaths, governors pleaded for a consistent strategy and more help from Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the surgeon general told the nation to brace for “our Pearl Harbor moment” of cascading coronavirus deaths this week, several governors said on Sunday that their states were in urgent need of federal help and complained that they had been left to compete for critical equipment in the absence of a consistent strategy and coordination from the Trump administration.
articles.byline: By Rick Rojas and Vanessa Swales

articles.headline: He Led a Top Navy Ship. Now He Sits in Quarantine, Fired and Infected.
articles.snippet: Colleagues say the downfall of Capt. Brett E. Crozier was charging headlong into the Trump administration’s narrative that it had everything in the coronavirus pandemic under control.
articles.abstract: Colleagues say the downfall of Capt. Brett E. Crozier was charging headlong into the Trump administration’s narrative that it had everything in the coronavirus pandemic under control.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For days, he fended off fears that the contagion would spread unchecked through his crew. Then last week, the captain of the aircraft carrier Theodore Roosevelt, who had appealed to his superiors for help, was fired.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and John Ismay

articles.headline: Americans Don’t Trust the Media Anymore. So Why Do They Trust the Cuomos?
articles.snippet: CNN once prevented Chris Cuomo from interviewing his brother on the air. But that all changed with the arrival of the coronavirus, and now it’s changing television, too.
articles.abstract: CNN once prevented Chris Cuomo from interviewing his brother on the air. But that all changed with the arrival of the coronavirus, and now it’s changing television, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the end of 2013, CNN executives sent word to Chris Cuomo: No more interviewing your brother on television.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: European Banks Prepared for a Crisis. But Not This One.
articles.snippet: The financial impact of the coronavirus surpasses the old worst-case scenarios, threatening a credit crunch or even a new financial crisis.
articles.abstract: The financial impact of the coronavirus surpasses the old worst-case scenarios, threatening a credit crunch or even a new financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — It was supposed to be a drill. Government overseers would test whether European banks could survive a hypothetical perfect storm that included a steep economic downturn, plunging stock prices and a collapse in consumer spending.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Young Adults, Burdened With Debt, Are Now Facing an Economic Crisis
articles.snippet: Young people who entered this financial downturn with fewer resources than previous generations are enduring pain.
articles.abstract: Young people who entered this financial downturn with fewer resources than previous generations are enduring pain.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last time a serious economic downturn hit in 2008, Evan Schade was in high school and the crisis seemed like a news event that happened to other people. This time, as the coronavirus has brought the economy to its knees, it has become a personal affair.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: ‘Scared to Death’ by Arbitration: Companies Drowning in Their Own System
articles.snippet: Lawyers and a Silicon Valley start-up have found ways to flood the system with claims, so companies are looking to thwart a process they created.
articles.abstract: Lawyers and a Silicon Valley start-up have found ways to flood the system with claims, so companies are looking to thwart a process they created.
articles.lead_paragraph: Teel Lidow couldn’t quite believe the numbers. Over the past few years, the nation’s largest telecom companies, like Comcast and AT&T, have had a combined 330 million customers. Yet annually an average of just 30 people took the companies to arbitration, the forum where millions of Americans are forced to hash out legal disputes with corporations.
articles.byline: By Michael Corkery and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: As School Moves Online, Many Students Stay Logged Out
articles.snippet: Teachers at some schools across the country report that fewer than half of their students are participating in online learning.
articles.abstract: Teachers at some schools across the country report that fewer than half of their students are participating in online learning.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chronic absenteeism is a problem in American education during the best of times, but now, with the vast majority of the nation’s school buildings closed and lessons being conducted remotely, more students than ever are missing class — not logging on, not checking in or not completing assignments.
articles.byline: By Dana Goldstein, Adam Popescu and Nikole Hannah-Jones
